entry.title: Combined summary - Proposal: Bundled payments
entry.summary: Thomas Voegtlin has proposed an extension to BOLT-11 protocol for atomic swaps. The proposal involves two bundled payments with distinct preimages and amounts, aimed at services that require prepayment of a mining fee for a non-custodian exchange to take place, including submarine swaps and JIT channels. The proposed change would level the field in terms of competition between lightning service providers. Currently, a dedicated client is required to use Loop, creating an advantage for competitors who do not have an established user base running a dedicated client. This exposes them to the mining fee attack. Thomas believes that ACINQ would benefit from this feature as it would allow their pay-to-open service to be fully non-custodian. The decision to make this feature required or optional remains with the service provider. However, Matt Corallo responded by stating that creating a new interoperable change to BOLT-11 may not be feasible at this point. He suggests working towards specifying a "standard" way of doing swaps built on onion messages (OMs) so that it can be done more privately. The semantics of bundled payments involve waiting for all HTLCs of both payments before fulfilling the pre-payment. Updating Bolt 12 is a better alternative than updating Bolt 11, which requires senders to be aware that the payment will lead to a channel creation or a splice on the receiver end, and it requires all existing software used by senders to be updated.In response to Thomas's question about the difference between splice-out and submarine swaps, Corallo explained that submarine swaps allow for the addition of receiving capacity to a channel. While Thomas's proposal may have limitations, the conversation highlights ongoing discussions around the development of atomic swap features within the Bitcoin ecosystem.
